Fig. 1 SEM images of NiO (a). Co3O4 (b, c). NiO/Co3O4 (d, e). EDS spectrum image of NiO/Co3O4 in selected area (inserted image) (f) and elemental mapping images of NiO/Co3O4 for O, Co, Ni (g-i). XRD patterns of the NiO, Co3O4, NiO/Co3O4 (j). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of Co3O4 and NiO/Co3O4 composites (k). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Cyclic voltammograms (CV) (a), Nyquist plots (b) of NiO, Co3O4, NiO/Co3O4 composites as working electrode and SCE as the reference electrode in 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution. The degradation efficiency of NiO/Co3O4, Co3O4 and NiO to LEV (c). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The degradation efficiency and kinetic analysis of the electrochemical degradation of LEV by changing the initial pH (a, b), initial concentration (c, d), current density (e, f) and the EE/O under different condition (g). Experimental conditions: C(LEV) = 30 mg L−1, j = 30 mA cm−2 for (a), pH = 3, j = 30 mA cm−2 for (c), pH = 3, C(LEV) = 30 mg L−1 for (e). Errors represent the standard deviation (n = 3). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 COD removal rate (a), H2O2 production (b) of NiO/Co3O4 electrodes in LEV degradation: initial concentration: 30 mg L−1; current density: 30 mA cm−2; initial pH: 3; electrolyte: 0.1 M Na2SO4. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of (a) Ni 2p and (b) Co 2p in NiO/Co3O4 composite before and after LEV degradation. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The interface mechanism of NiO/Co3O4 cathode degradation of LEV. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 UV–vis spectra (a). A representative chromatogram of oxidized samples obtained by a GC-MS method (b). Plausible LEV degradation pathway through Fenton-like process was determined (c). A sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite cathode was synthesized by two-step hydrothermal in-situ growth method and a Fenton-like process inducing two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) was established to degrade levofloxacin (LEV) in this paper. NiO/Co3O4 exhibited higher specific surface area and better electrical conductivity comparing with NiO or Co3O4, indicating an excellent synergistic effect between NiO and Co3O4. Moreover, NiO/Co3O4 cathode could effectively degrade LEV wastewater, the removal efficiency could reach 77.8% after 120 min and the corresponding COD removal efficiency was 41.0%. Further studies showed that the effective conversion of Co(Ⅱ)/Co(Ⅲ) and Ni(Ⅱ)/Ni(Ⅲ) occurred on the electrode surface, which promoted the generation of •OH. Finally, a possible degradation pathway of LEV involved defluorination, deamination, demethylation and other processes was proposed. In short, the research could provide important reference for solving electrochemical problems related to electrocatalytic ORR and Fenton-like degradation of antibiotic wastewater. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 In-situ growth Oxygen reduction reaction Fenton-like LEV degradation 1 Introduction Antibiotics is one of the most widely used drugs in the medical field. In particular, levofloxacin (LEV) is a typical fluoroquinolones (FQs) antibiotic with the ability to degrade microorganisms, and has a wide range of clinical uses [1]. It is used to treat various respiratory and urinary tracts and resist most Gram-positive intestinal diseases as well as skin infections and Gram-negative bacteria [2]. However, most antibiotics cannot be completely absorbed by the human body, and are mainly released into the environment as metabolites or even in their raw [3]. Unfortunately, LEV has strong bio-resistance, which is almost impossible to be biodegraded, leading to widespread detection of LEV residues in surface water, groundwater and sediments [4]. Therefore, it is urgent to develop feasible pharmaceutical wastewater purification technologies for the water environment safety. It has been reported that the technologies to eliminate fluoroquinolones mainly include photocatalysis, chlorine dioxide oxidation and electrochemical oxidation [5–7]. Among them, electrochemical advanced oxidation processes (EAOPs) have shown convincing degradation efficiency of organic pollutants and have been applied to effectively eliminate LEV due to its high oxidation, practical operation and environmental compatibility [8], such as electron-Fenton [9], Fenton-like [10], electrocatalysis oxidation [11,12]. In general, the basic mechanism of Fenton system is that Fe2+ and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) generate hydroxyl radical through Fenton reaction without additional H2O2 as shown in following Eqs. (1)–(3) [13,14]. The electro-Fenton system based on Fe-based material modification as the cathode has attracted wide attention, and it exhibits good oxidation/mineralization efficiency for persistent organic pollutants [15–17]. Moreover, the Fenton-like process in which the iron ion replaced by transition metals such as Cu, Co, Ni, Mn and others in the redox reaction has also been widely reported, such as Cu2(OH)3NO3 [18], Co/MCM [19]. Khan et al. [20] proved that CuCo@MnO2 with a quadrangular structure could effectively activate epoxy sulfate to synergistically degrade phenolic pollutants. The experimental results showed that 0.5% Cu-2% Co-MnO2 could effectively degrade 30 ppm of phenol, while 0.5% Cu@MnO2 or 2% Co@MnO2 monomer degraded phenol very slowly, which proved the double of Cu and Co had a significant synergistic effect between metal oxides. Jia et al. [21] successfully synthesized a series of Z-scheme MnOx/g-C3N4 nanocomposites with high surface area, which was used as effective stable photo-electro catalysts to degrade ciprofloxacin (CIP) for the first time, and the removal of CIP reached 96.23% within 2 h. (1) O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - =H 2 O 2 (2) Fe 3 + + e - =Fe 2 + (3) Fe 2 + + H 2 O 2 =Fe 3 + + •OH+ OH − As is well-known, material is the key factor that affects the Fenton-like efficiency. Single metal oxide with simple components usually shows relatively limited physical and chemical properties [22]. In contrast, bimetal oxide composite materials could exhibit better characteristics than single metal oxides and inherit the advantages of each component [23,24]. Generally, bimetal oxides have a large number of oxygen vacancies and a high specific surface area, which can provide more electrochemically active sites [25]. In addition, the heterogeneous interface can provide richer redox reactions, thereby promoting the improvement of electrochemical performance [26]. Co3O4 is one of the most common materials in Fenton-like reactions with inverted spinel crystal structure, and multivalence Co element exhibits a p-type semiconducting property. As a result of its environmental benignity, low-cost, it has acquired extensively research interest [27]. Moreover, Co3O4 materials can be facilely synthesized to afford various morphologies, and thus, they exhibit distinct catalytic activities owing to their different physical characteristics, chemical properties, and exposed crystal planes [28]. However, Co3O4 has poor charge storage capacity due to its poor conductivity and low utilization at high current density [29]. According to the literature [30], some researchers put forward the concept of bimetal oxide composite to improve the conductivity and effectively use Co3O4. Meanwhile, NiO has good electrochemical activity, reversibility, chemical stability, easily changeable chemical valence (NiO, NiOOH, Ni(OH)2). So, it has a wide range of applications in gas sensors, electrocatalysis, fuel cell electrodes, photovoltaic devices and batteries [31,32]. Therefore, many scientists have conducted NiO/Co3O4 research on above basis. Wang et al. [33] synthesized NiO/Co3O4-graphene foam (GF) composite material through solution immersion and subsequent annealing treatment, and the composite material had excellent electrochemical performance, better electron transfer rate and excellent cycle stability. Besides, NiO/Co3O4 nanofiber catalysts were also fabricated by the low-cost and simple electrospinning method, and the catalytic activity was greatly improved [34]. However, NiO/Co3O4 has very few applications in Fenton-like degradation of organic wastewater, and we speculate that it will also have potential value in this regard. Hence, the sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite was successfully synthesized by in-situ growth method and applied to the degradation of LEV in antibiotic wastewater. Then the reaction parameters affecting electro-Fenton degradation was comprehensively analyzed. Subsequently, we discussed the changes in the valence states of Co and Ni and the catalytic mechanism during the Fenton-like reaction on the electrode surface. Finally, the intermediate was identified by GC-MS and combined with UV–visible spectroscopy, the possible degradation pathway of LEV was proposed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Reagents and materials Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), ammonium fluoride, absolute ethyl alcohol, acetone, and hydrochloric acid, urea (U) were purchased from Kelon Chemical Reagent Factory (Tianjin, China). LEV was produced by Shanghai Aladdin Chemical Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). The purity of all chemicals and reagents is AR and they are dissolved in distilled water. Nickel Foam (NF) sheets (50 mm × 20 mm × 1 mm) were purchased from Baoji Longsheng Nonferrous Metal Co., Ltd. (shaanxi, China). Some more information about the chemical agents in this work is listed in Table S1. 2.2 Electrodes fabrication Firstly, nickel foam was pretreated to ensure well adhesion between electrode surface active layer and nickel foam. The effective area of the foamed nickel was 8 cm2 (2 cm × 4 cm). Foam nickel was then ultrasonically cleaned with acetone, hydrochloric acid (3 mol L−1, 24.8 mL of 12 mol L−1 hydrochloric acid and 50 mL of deionized water), anhydrous ethanol, deionized water for 20 min, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 50 ℃ for 2 h [35]. 2.2 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 11 mmol NH4F and 27.5 mmol urea were dissolved in 44 mL deionized water, followed by ultrasound for 10 min. Then, the prepared precursor solution and the pre-prepared nickel foam were transferred to polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) autoclave and kept in an oven at 120 ℃ for 16 h for in situ hydrothermal growth. After being cooled naturally to 25 °C, they were removed and washed thoroughly twice with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and then dried in 50 °C air for 3 h. Finally, the obtained product was put into an alumina boat and calcined at 400 °C for 2 h, then naturally cooled to 25 °C to obtain the NiO-NF electrode [36]. Dissolve 15 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 15 mmol NH4F and 15 mmol urea in 44 mL deionized water and ultrasonic for 10 min. The prepared precursor solution and the NiO/NF in the previous step were transferred to PTFE autoclave and kept in the oven at 100 °C for 11 h, and the products were removed by in-situ hydrothermal growth. Washing thoroughly 3 times with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol and then drying in 50 °C air for 3 h. Finally, the obtained product was put into an alumina boat and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h, then naturally cooled to 25 °C to obtain the NiO/Co3O4-NF electrode [37]. 2.3 Characterization of the electrodes The morphologies of the NiO, Co3O4 and NiO/Co3O4 composite were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi-s5) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS, FEI/Quanta 400) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100). The X-ray diffraction method (XRD, Bruke D8 Advance) patterns were applied for the exploration of the crystal structure of NiO, Co3O4 and NiO/Co3O4 composite electrodes. The surface area analyzer (BET, MICROMERITICS ASAP2460) was used to determine the specific surface area of the NiO/Co3O4-NF and Co3O4-NF composites. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB250Xi) of the NiO/Co3O4 composite was used to measure the valence state of element of the NiO/Co3O4 composite. 2.4 Electrochemical tests Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) and Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) were carried out in a constant temperature electrolyzer (250 mL) with magnetic stirring. A three-electrode system was constructed with NiO-NF, Co3O4-NF and NiO/Co3O4-NF as the working electrode in sequence, SCE as the reference electrode and stainless steel (SS) as the electrode. And the effective surface area of the working electrode and the counter electrode was 8.0 cm2. The electrochemical workstation system (CHI660D, Shanghai) was used for testing in 0.1 M Na2SO4. 2.5 The procedure of LEV degradation Degradation reaction was carried out in 250 mL glass beaker at room temperature (25 °C) with stirring at 100 rpm. And the NiO/Co3O4 was used as cathode, graphite was used as anode. The two electrodes are the same size and placed in parallel with a distance of 4 cm. Different Fenton-like conditions, the degradation in this work were performed at a constant current provided by a DC power supply (HY3005ET, Shenzhen Huayi Instrument Co., LTD., China) in supporting electrolyte sodium sulfate aqueous solutions (0.1 M). 2.6 Analytical methods The absorbance at the maximum absorption wavelength of 293 nm was measured by a dual-beam ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometer (UV-6100pcs, Shanghai Mapada Instrument Co., Ltd.), and the degradation efficiency of LEV was calculated [38]. The calculation method was derived from the Lambert-Beer law as shown in Eq. (4) [39]. Chemical oxygen demand (COD) could be often used as an analysis indicator of wastewater degradation efficiency [40]. The COD value was determined by rapid digestion and spectrophotometry with Orion COD165 (America, Thermo) and UV–vis spectrophotometer. The concentration of H2O2 was determined by iodization with taking appropriate amount of solution every 20 min. And the •OH in the Fenton reaction was detected by electron spin resonance (EPR, A200) with 5, 5-dimethyl-L-pyrroline noxide (DMPO) as spin-trapping agent. In order to further verify the effect of the •OH, quenching experiment was also carried out by adding a quencher MeOH to the solution before the degradation. The intermediate product identification was performed on an Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph (Agilent, Wilmington, DE, USA). (4) The degradation efficiency of LEV = ( A 0 - A t ) A 0 × 100 % where A0 and At were the initial and final values of the LEV absorbance, respectively, which were related to the initial (C0) and final (Ct) concentrations of LEV according to the Lambert-Beer law. The processing cost of technical processes was a very important parameter for industrial applications. Analyzing energy consumption was essential for economic benefit evaluation. The electrical efficiency (EE/O) of each logarithmic order was used to describe the electrical energy (in kWh) consumed to degrade LEV, using the following Eq. (5). (5) EE/O( k Wh m - 3 ) = U×I×t V× log ( A 0 /A t ) where U was the average cell voltage (V), I was the applied current (A), t was the electrolysis time (h), V was the wastewater volume (L), A0 and At were the initial and final values of the absorbance of LEV. EE/O was a vital factor in assessing degradation performance. To evaluate the degradation performance of LEV more specifically, the kinetic analysis was used. The removal of LEV followed a pseudo first-order reaction (Eq. (6)). The NiO exhibited silk-like texture and evenly covered the surface of the substrate (Fig. 1a). The Co3O4, covered by uniform and dense spine, showed sea urchin-like texture with a diameter of about 2 µm (Fig. 1b and c). However, when the sea urchin-like Co3O4 grew in-situ hydrothermally on the surface of NiO, the covered spines on the outer surface would become much denser (Fig. 1d–e). It meant that the specific surface area would increase accordingly, then we have done the corresponding BET characterization via nitrogen isothermal adsorption/desorption measurements, and the corresponding data in Fig. 1k confirmed that the specific surface area of NiO/Co3O4-NF (23.25 m2 g−1) was greater than that of Co3O4-NF (20.20 m2 g−1). The element composition of the material was characterized by EDS technology. Fig. 1f–i showed the energy spectrum of the composite material and the mapping distribution of each element. Obviously, the composite material was composed of O, Co and Ni and the distribution morphology of each element was basically the same, which was consistent with the morphology of NiO/Co3O4 in SEM selected areas. Thus, it proved that all of the elements were evenly distributed in the sample. Fig. 1j showed the XRD spectra of NiO, Co3O4 and NiO/Co3O4 composites. There were three weak diffraction peaks for NiO at 37.25°, 43.27° and 75.41°, corresponding to the representative (111), (200), (311) crystal planes, respectively, and all peaks could be indexed in JCPDS file No. 47-1049 [41]. The characteristic peaks of Co3O4 were (311), (400), (511) at around 36.93°, 44.78°, 59.50°, respectively, which was consistent with the reference pattern (JCPDS No. 42-1467) [42]. In the NiO/Co3O4 composite material, the diffraction peaks of NiO and Co3O4 could be detected at the same time. However, the peak intensity of NiO was relatively low or even partially offset, which might be due to the changes in the NiO lattice caused by external Co3O4. Combined with the aforementioned results, it could be confirmed that NiO and Co3O4 were successfully composited. At the same time, this kind of sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite material could increase electrocatalytic active sites and improve electrochemical performance. 3.2 Electrochemical properties The electrocatalytic ORR activity of NiO-NF, Co3O4-NF, NiO/Co3O4-NF was evaluated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) via a typical three-electrode setup in 0.1 M Na2SO4. Fig. 2a showed the electrochemical response of three different working electrodes in the range of −0.2–1.0 V (vs. RHE) with a scan speed of 0.05 V s−1 in 0.1 M Na2SO4. Apparently, NiO/Co3O4 had a greater and wider response current than single NiO or Co3O4, which could indicate that this composite electrode had better electrocatalytic activity. Fig. 2b was the Nyquist diagram of NiO, Co3O4 and NiO/Co3O4 in a 0.1 M Na2SO4 solution at 0.01–100,000 Hz. The Nyquist plot includes a semicircular part represented the charge transfer resistance (Ret) and a linear part with diffusion-limiting steps. Especially, the radius of the semicircle in the high-frequency range indicates that Ret controls the redox reaction occurring at the electrode-electrolyte interface to a certain extent [43]. The semicircle diameter of NiO/Co3O4 electrodes was significantly reduced compared with NiO and Co3O4 electrodes, and the Ret values of NiO, Co3O4 and NiO/Co3O4 electrodes were 98.68, 61.23 and 18.92 kΩ, respectively. Therefore, it could be proved that the NiO/Co3O4 composite electrode had better conductivity and could accelerate the transfer of electrons on the electrode surface. The results further confirmed that the sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite material had the synergistic effect of NiO and Co3O4, which accelerated the interface charge transfer and improved the ORR catalytic performance, thereby enhancing the Fenton-like efficiency. As shown in Fig. 2c, under the same degradation conditions, the degradation efficiency of NiO/Co3O4, Co3O4 and NiO to LEV were 77.8%, 67.2% and 49.6%, respectively, and the result better illustrated the above conclusions. 3.3 The performance of LEV degradation on NiO/Co3O4 cathode In order to analyze and discuss the Fenton-like performance of NiO/Co3O4 electrode in more depth. Table 1 summarized the removal rate of LEV, k value, R2 value and EE/O value. These results were anlyzed as follows. Generally, pH value was a crucial factor in the Fenton-like system according to equation [44] (7) •OH+H 2 O 2 = O 2 - + H + + H 2 O Fig. 3a showed the effect of pH on the degradation of 30 mg L−1 LEV simulated wastewater. It could be seen that in the same degradation time, when pH = 3, the degradation efficiency was the highest (77.8%), but the degradation rate would decrease significantly as the pH value increased. When pH = 9, the degradation efficiency was reduced to 52.1%. As shown in Fig. 3b, the degradation rate constants of 3, 5, 7, and 9 at different pH values were 0.013, 0.011, 0.009, and 0.006 min−1, respectively. When the pH increased from 3 to 9, the rate constant gradually decreased. This phenomenon could be explained by the free radical generation mechanism. Generally speaking, acidic conditions were conducive to the degradation of LEV. Because the H2O2 generated by the ORR reaction on the cathode surface was the source of •OH, and •OH was more effective in a strong acid environment, thus, it could significantly accelerate the degradation of materials near the electrode [45]. But at the beginning of the reaction, if the pH value was too low, it was likely to cause severe corrosion of the electrode, and even inhibit the catalytic activity of the electrode in severe cases [46]. After comprehensive analysis and comparison, the best pH was 3. It could be seen from Fig. 3c that the initial concentration of LEV was 10–50 mg L−1 for degrading 120 min, the degradation efficiency of LEV at low concentration level was much higher than that at high concentration level. As shown in Fig. 3d, the corresponding rate constants at different concentrations of 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 mg L−1 were 0.015, 0.014, 0.013, 0.011 and 0.010, respectively. The formation and consumption of •OH maintained a dynamic balance when the current was constant. If the concentration of organic matter in the solution continued to increase, the relative content of •OH in the entire system would continue to decrease, and the oxidation effect would be weakened. Additionally, higher concentration would cause more intermediates to appear during the reaction, and they were likely to be adsorbed on the electrode surface, which would greatly inhibit the degradation efficiency. Therefore, combining energy consumption and degradation efficiency, an initial concentration of 30 mg L−1 was a better choice. Current density was one of the key factors to control the effectiveness of the electric Fenton process, which adjusted the amount of •OH and H2O2, thereby oxidizing the organic matter in the solution. Generally speaking, higher current density could generate more •OH, thereby increasing degradation efficiency of LEV [47]. It could be seen from Fig. 3e that as the current density increased, the increase in the production of H2O2 was conducive to the formation of active reactive oxygen species (ROS), so we could see the degradation rate of LEV also increased in Fig. 3f. After 120 min of degradation at 10–50 mA cm−2, the degradation efficiency of LEV was 71.4%, 73.1%, 77.8%, 78.9% and 79.5%, respectively. The detailed data of EE/O were shown in Table 1 and Fig. 3g, which could further explain the additional energy consumption of LEV degradation. In general, the negative effect of increasing current on the reaction would consume excess •OH and energy [48]. Considering the degradation efficiency and energy consume, the current density of 30 mA cm−2 was selected in this study. Taking into account the energy consumption of EE/O and the removal of LEV, the pH value of 3, the current density of 30 mA cm−2 and the initial LEV concentration of 30 mg L−1 were determined as the optimal conditions for the degradation study. Compared with the system reported in the literatures (Table S2), the NiO/Co3O4 cathode showed comparable LEV degradation. And the electrical energy consumption in this work was also slightly reduced. Thus, NiO/Co3O4 cathode was a promising candidate in degradation of antibiotic wastewater. Subsequently, we analyzed the mineralization efficiency of the material in wastewater treatment by detecting the COD content in the solution. Because LEV had a complex macromolecular structure, the removal rate of COD was very poor in the first half hour of the degradation process, but after 120 min, the removal rate of COD could reach 41.0% as shown in Fig. 4a. Besides, it could be seen from Fig. 4b that during the degradation process, the surface of the NiO/Co3O4 cathode would continuously produce H2O2, maintaining the stability of the Fenton-like process. Quenching experiment and EPR analysis further indicated that the Fenton-like reaction effectively promoted the formation of •OH (Fig. S2), thereby, effectively degrading LEV. Moreover, the cyclic experiment and the metal leaching analysis were performed to evaluate the stability of the NiO/Co3O4 electrode, and the relevant statement was in Supporting information (Text S2 and Fig. S3 and S4). In summary, NiO/Co3O4 cathode had certain application potential in the field of Fenton-like wastewater degradation. 3.4 Interface reaction mechanism for the Fenton-like performance of NiO/Co3O4 According to the previous electrochemical performance analysis, it could be proved that the combination of NiO and Co3O4 could effectively improve the catalytic activity and enhance the Fenton-like degradation of organics effectiveness. In order to deeply explore the interface mechanism of NiO/Co3O4 cathode degradation of LEV, XPS was used to analyze the element valence states of Co and Ni on the surface of NiO/Co3O4 cathode before and after degradation, and the possible Fenton-like interface reaction mechanism was inferred. As shown in Fig. 5, the Ni 2p contained several peaks. Peaks around 855.5 eV and 873.0 eV could be assigned to Ni2+ 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 states, whilst the peak around 861 eV probably belonged to the Ni2+ 2p3/2 satellite signal arising from multiplet splitting. However, there appeared new peaks at the binding energy of 857.18 eV and 874.9 eV after degradation, confirming the presence of Ni3+ induced by the redox reaction [49]. Similarly, the Co 2p signal also exhibited two different types of binding energies, which were considered to be two different cobalt substances. It could be seen that the peak area ratio of Co(Ⅲ) with a binding energy of 780.6 eV and Co(Ⅱ) with a binding energy of 782.3 eV before and after the degradation became larger, which could be inferred that Co(Ⅱ) would transform to Co(Ⅲ) during the redox process [50]. The above was similar to the analysis and speculation of metal ions at the Fenton-like interface participating in the reaction. As shown in Fig. 6, the overall conversion of Ni(Ⅱ)/Ni(Ⅲ) and Co(Ⅱ)/Co(Ⅲ) was most likely to proceed through the following steps: O2 received 2-electrons through the reduction reaction as in Eqs. (8) and (9), it could be generated H2O2 on the cathode surface. Subsequently, H2O2 would undergo lots of redox with Co and Ni, and continuously generated ROS such as •OH. The Ni(Ⅱ)/Ni(Ⅲ) and Co(Ⅱ)/Co(Ⅲ) transition cycles promoted the conversion of H2O2 to •OH, thereby promoting Fenton-like reactions (Eqs. (10)–(16)) [51–53]. As a result, the degradation of LEV in the solution was achieved, and it was broken down into small molecular organic fragments (OF) (Eq. (17)) [54]. The following equation showed the reactions involved: (8) O 2 + 2 H 2 O+ 2 e - = H 2 O 2 + 2 O H - (9) 2 H + + O 2 + 2 e - =H 2 O 2 (10) Co 3 + + e - =Co 2 + (11) Co 2 + + H 2 O 2 =Co 3 + +•OH+O H - (12) Co 3 + + H 2 O 2 =Co 2 + + O 2 - + 2 H + (13) Co 2 + + H + + H 2 O 2 =Co 3 + +•OH+ H 2 O (14) Ni 2 + + H 2 O 2 =Ni 3 + +•OH+O H - (15) Ni 3 + + e - =Ni 2 + (16) Ni 2 + + H + + H 2 O 2 =Ni 3 + +•OH+ H 2 O (17) LEV+•OH=OF+ H 2 O+C O 2 ↑ 3.5 Evolution of intermediates and degradation pathways of LEV According to the above results, the degradation efficiency of LEV could reach 77.8% within 2 h, and the COD removal rate was about 41.0%. Simultaneously, combined with the changes in the UV–vis spectrum, it could indicate that a large number of difficult-to-decompose intermediates were produced during the degradation process by-product. As shown in Fig. 7a, the absorption peak at 293 nm decreased significantly with the increase of degradation time, indicating that the content of LEV was decreasing. This was mainly because the characteristic groups of LEV were attacked by ROS during the degradation process [55]. To further investigate the LEV degradation pathways, GC-MS was used to identify organic matter produced during degradation. A typical GC-MS chromatogram of LEV degradation was shown in Fig. 7b, and the intermediate product information was shown in the Supporting information (Table S3). According to the intermediate product L2-L10 in Fig. 7c, the decomposition of LEV was mainly caused by the oxidation of the quinolone ring by defluorination, decarboxylation, and cleavage of piperazine [56]. Combined with the structures of L2, L5, L8, and L10, we could infer that quinolone drugs would undergo decarboxylation under the attack of hydroxyl radicals [57]. The F ions in L2, L5, L9, and L10 were replaced by hydroxyl groups [58,59], indicating that LEV had been defluorinated. It could be seen from L3, L4, L6, L7, L9 that the piperazine structure became an amino group under the oxidation of active oxygen and underwent different degrees of cleavage [60]. After continuous defluorination, decarboxylation, ring-opening reaction of aromatics, loss of piperazinyl group and demethylation process, the molecular structure of quinolone was gradually simplified, and some intermediates were transformed into L11, L12, L13, L14 and other substances [61]. Among them, L12, L13 were formed due to the ring-opening reaction of the morpholinyl group [62]. Later, the intermediate products might continue to be subdivided into small molecular organic acids and mineralized products. In summary, LEV was gradually decomposed into small molecular organic matter under the action of Fenton-like and converted to water, carbon dioxide and other inorganic substances to a certain extent [63]. We also roughly evaluated the toxicity of the intermediate products through a simple antibacterial experiment [64–66]. Fig. S5 showed the images of the cultured plate with the E. coli strain bacteriostatic zone. It could be observed that the inhibition zone gradually decreased and the surrounding bacterial colonies also increased significantly with the increment of degradation time. The result further proved that the NiO/Co3O4 cathode could effectively reduce the toxicity of LEV during the degradation process. 4 Conclusion A sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite cathode has been successfully synthesized by a two-step hydrothermal in-situ growth route. The nanocomposites could generate H2O2 through a two-electron ORR, and then initiated a Fenton-like reaction under constant current conditions to achieve effective degradation of LEV. Compared with NiO or Co3O4, NiO/Co3O4 exhibited higher specific surface area and better electrical conductivity, indicating an excellent synergistic effect between NiO and Co3O4. Then the effect of operational parameters on the Fenton-like degradation were studied, the optimal parameters for degradation of target pollutants were: pH = 3, j = 30 mA cm−2, and c(LEV) = 30 mg L−1, the removal efficiency of LEV was relatively high, reaching 77.8%. The material also showed considerable COD removal rate (41.0%) and H2O2 production in degradation applications, which showed practical application value. In addition, the reaction mechanism of the cathode surface was inferred from the XPS analysis results. The H2O2 generated by the 2-electron ORR promoted the redox with Co2+ and Ni2+ on the electrode surface to induce a Fenton-like process, thereby promoting the formation of more ROS in the solution, leading to organic molecules that were prone to oxidation and dissociation. According to the morphology and electrochemical analysis of the electrode, it could be inferred that the NiO/Co3O4 cathode had a higher activity of oxygen reduction catalytic and Fenton-like reaction. Finally, based on the results of GC-MS and UV–vis, the degradation pathway of LEV was analyzed: Macromolecular organic matter was decomposed into simple aromatic hydrocarbons through defluorination, deamination, demethylation and other processes, and small inorganic molecules such as water and carbon dioxide were continuously produced under the action of ROS. The results showed that NiO/Co3O4 composite material could be used as an effective cathode for Fenton-like catalytic degradation of organic pollutants. coredata.dc:description: A sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite cathode was synthesized by two-step hydrothermal in-situ growth method and a Fenton-like process inducing two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) was established to degrade levofloxacin (LEV) in this paper. NiO/Co3O4 exhibited higher specific surface area and better electrical conductivity comparing with NiO or Co3O4, indicating an excellent synergistic effect between NiO and Co3O4. Moreover, NiO/Co3O4 cathode could effectively degrade LEV wastewater, the removal efficiency could reach 77.8% after 120 min and the corresponding COD removal efficiency was 41.0%. Further studies showed that the effective conversion of Co(Ⅱ)/Co(Ⅲ) and Ni(Ⅱ)/Ni(Ⅲ) occurred on the electrode surface, which promoted the generation of •OH. Finally, a possible degradation pathway of LEV involved defluorination, deamination, demethylation and other processes was proposed. In short, the research could provide important reference for solving electrochemical problems related to electrocatalytic ORR and Fenton-like degradation of antibiotic wastewater.
coredata.dc:title: A novel electrochemical cathode based on sea urchin-like NiO/Co3O4 composite inducing efficient Fenton-like process for levofloxacin degradation
